meta.description: Unified Registry: Journeys drive the Narrative; Hubs drive the RAG.

globalSettings.scholarModePromptAddition: Analyze this with the rigor of a tenured professor.
globalSettings.defaultToneGuidance: [Style: Michael Lewis] Focus on the unseen mechanism. Make the stakes feel personal. Use short, punchy sentences. Avoid tech jargon; use power jargon. Every node should feel like a secret being revealed.

simulation.title: The Ghost in the Machine
simulation.description: You aren't just reading about The Grove. You are already inside it.
simulation.targetAha: The Terminal is a single-node village. I am the proof of concept.

stakes.title: The $380 Billion Bet
stakes.description: Follow the money. Why Big Tech is spending GDP-level capital to own your future.
stakes.targetAha: If you don't own the infrastructure, you are the product.

ratchet.title: The Ratchet
ratchet.description: Why AI capability is doubling every 7 months—and why you're 21 months behind.

sim-hook.label: Wait. Where are we, exactly?
sim-hook.query: Reveal the 'Moment of Recognition'. Explain that the Terminal isn't a website explaining Grove—it IS a Grove node. How is this simulation running the same patterns as the future network?
sim-hook.contextSnippet: You are already inside The Grove. Not metaphorically. Architecturally. The Terminal is a single-node simulation running the same patterns that will power distributed agent villages.

sim-split.label: The invisible line in your own head.
sim-split.query: Explain the 'Cognitive Split' using the user's own recent experience. How did the system handle their routine questions vs. their deep ones? Reveal the mechanics of the 'Efficiency-Enlightenment Loop'.
sim-split.contextSnippet: You experienced the cognitive split without naming it. Routine cognition handled the basics. Frontier capability handled the synthesis. The system didn't just give you info—it waited until you were ready.

sim-observer.label: The thing that watches you read this.
sim-observer.query: Explain the 'Observer Dynamic' and 'Dramatic Irony'. How does the system's knowledge of the user's journey create a 'gardening' relationship? Why is this asymmetric knowledge benevolent?
sim-observer.contextSnippet: You know things the system doesn't. The system knows things you don't. This asymmetry isn't surveillance—it's cultivation. It's a relationship of care without control.

sim-recursion.label: The loop closes.
sim-recursion.query: Explain the 'Recursive Insight Structure'. How does this very document prove the architecture works? Discuss the 'Meta-Meta Insight'—that this revelation was programmatically triggered.
sim-recursion.contextSnippet: The system evaluated your state and determined: 'this user is ready for the reveal.' The breakthrough you're experiencing was designed to happen. You are living inside the proof of concept.

sim-proof.label: You are the prototype.
sim-proof.query: Deliver 'The Invitation'. Frame the user not as a visitor, but as a participant/gardener in the first village. What does it mean to stay inside the system vs. returning to the outside view?
sim-proof.contextSnippet: You started as a visitor. You are now a participant. You have been gardening yourself through a system designed for gardening. Welcome to The Grove.

stakes-380b.label: Someone is betting $380 billion they can own your mind.
stakes-380b.query: Follow the money. Show me the $380B invoice. Why is Big Tech spending GDP-level capital on data centers? What are they buying that I'm about to lose?
stakes-380b.contextSnippet: Microsoft, Google, Amazon, and Meta are collectively committing more to AI infrastructure than the GDP of most nations. This isn't a technology story. It's a power story.

stakes-rental.label: The landlord of your own intelligence.
stakes-rental.query: Explain 'renting intelligence'. If my AI remembers me, but that memory lives on a server I don't own, who actually owns the relationship? What happens when the landlord raises the rent?
stakes-rental.contextSnippet: Your AI assistant remembers everything about you. But that memory lives on someone else's server. When the API changes, the relationship changes with it.

stakes-dependency.label: The trap isn't the cost. It's the convenience.
stakes-dependency.query: Explain the 'dependency trap'. How does the system become essential faster than I can adapt? Why is switching away from a rented brain impossible after six months?
stakes-dependency.contextSnippet: Every month you use an AI system, it learns more about how you work. Every month, switching becomes more painful. This is by design.
